meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay, well while we're finishing that up, why don't we just do the 30 second intro to each other. Um, so I'm I'll start. I'm Brian Pogue, I'm at Dartmouth College. I've worked here for 25 years in different types of imaging technologies, optical imaging technologies in medicine. Um, mostly macroscopic imaging, so I I call myself an anti-microscopist. Um, I mostly work on things that you can see.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, so why don't we go to Carolyn?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Carolyn Bayer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Carolyn Bayer. I'm an assistant professor at Tulane University. Um, my research is in photoacoustic imaging, um, with some contrast ultrasound thrown in and um, I primarily focus on preeclampsia, um, and studying vascular development and remodeling of the placenta.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay and next I'll just go by my screen, Katherine.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katharine White
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Katherine White. I'm an assistant professor at the University of Notre Dame and my lab sits at the interface of cancer cell biology and chemical biology. We develop new optogenetic tools that allow us to manipulate pH in space and time to better understand how spatial temporal pH dynamics regulate single cell behaviors and how this promotes um, uh, tumor genesis in in cancer development.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Okay and Shannon.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shannon Quinn
meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm an assistant professor at University of Georgia in computer science and biology. Um, and my lab revolves mostly around building computer vision machine learning tools for modeling spatial temporal changes in cellular systems in response to some kind of stimulus. Um, so I'm really excited about this discussion.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Okay and Brian.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bryan Spring
meeting_annotations.transcript: Everybody, I'm a physicist at Northeastern University. You can call me Bry to differentiate me from Brian Pogue. Um, and I work on photo medicine and um, cancer imaging and the imaging component is micro endoscopy, so miniature laser scanning microscopes to go inside the body and image with cellular resolution and we think a lot about multi photon.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: And for full disclosure, Brian and Brian do we we do collaborate through a P1, so we're kind of breaking the rules here, but anyway.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bryan Spring
meeting_annotations.transcript: We'll keep it a secret.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, Sue.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Seu Sim
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hello everyone. I'm an assistant professor at UC Irvine chemistry department and I'm actually a self material chemist, so I make materials with living bacterial cells. So I want to arrange bacterial communities in three-dimensional order, so this is a good topic and I want to see how people, you know, think about the big challenge issue of temporal imaging.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Okay and Larry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Huanyu Cheng
meeting_annotations.transcript: Good morning everyone. Uh my name is Larry. I'm also professor at Penn State University. Uh our focus in the group has been mostly on the deformable multi modality sensors for the medical application. And our uh interest with spatial imaging uh primarily related to the threshold uh photo acoustic imaging on the membrane for the imaging of the whole cortex layer and to a particular address issue with the skull and we are really happy to see how different modality will be able to combine for the enhanced spatial temporal resolution.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great. Okay and Josh.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Josh Brake
meeting_annotations.transcript: Everybody, my name is Josh Brake. I'm an assistant professor at Harvey Mudd College about 30 miles outside Los Angeles. And uh the focus of my group is on uh deep tissue imaging using optical wavefront shaping, trying to use scattered light to see deeper into tissue. And also a little bit of work in computational microscopy with a particular um uh edge looking at how we can use that for education and teaching optics. Um, I'm really looking forward to conversation with you all today.

Um, but we're also moving into low field MRI applications.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katy Keenan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Cool.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I love that topic. That's that's a nice one.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Uh, Nina. Hi, I'm Nina Cardoza. I'm director for grants and operations at the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative and I am an observer.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, okay.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: So where should we start?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Any initial thoughts?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: Or questions?

meeting_annotations.transcript: Wait, I have more questions than thoughts I think at this time.

meeting_annotations.transcript: Any any big questions that we shouldn't try to answer as a group?

meeting_annotations.transcript: I'm just curious how people do this right now.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Shannon Quinn
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, how folks here image across spatial and temporal domains?

meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, what are the things that work?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katy Keenan
meeting_annotations.transcript: One question I had when I looked at this is when we do work in MRI, we do a lot of under sampling uh and I don't know how much of that is done on the microscopy side. So we we do a lot of under sampling and then, you know, clever recon to try to find the information that you lost with your under sampling.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katy Keenan
meeting_annotations.transcript: So can anyone tell me what you guys what happens on the microscopy side?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brian Pogue
meeting_annotations.transcript: And by under sampling just to define that so you under sample in frequency space or something?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katy Keenan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yes, exactly. So in MRI we acquire in frequency space or K space and then we typically do a 4A transform to image space, but a lot of AI is replacing the 4A transform.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Katy Keenan
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um, and then you can do under sampling by acquiring less data and also by uh using more sensors essentially. So we have parallel coils but just increasing the number of sensors you have. So that's a common strategy that we use across imaging modalities.
